string_table.name: pxabnsnfns10110001101
string_table.string: To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.
Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: <Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Welcome to the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus Test module. Before we get started, please select your preferred language: English or Spanish. Select English if you would like to continue the module in English. Seleccione español si desea continuar el módulo en español." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Hello and welcome to the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus Test, otherwise known as the HGN Test, Training Module. This module will be split up into three main parts: Information, Practice, and Final Assessment. Within the information portion, we will be giving you a comprehensive overview of what the Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus test is and why this matters in field sobriety tests. From defining what nystagmus is to detailing out each step in the administeration of the test to what clue we are looking for while administering the test to ensure accurate and reliable results. Once you have finished the information portion, we will then move onto our practice portion. This is where you will complete a minimum of two out of three scenarios provided. You’ll be first given a field scenario where you will act as an officer identifying impairment in a subject. You will have to watch the subject's eyes as you administer the HGN test and determine if they are impaired or not. After that first field scenario, you can choose between two additional ones, whether it's practicing in another field scenario and testing another subject or defending your results in a courtroom. Once you have finished all these simulations you will move on to the final assessment where you would have to make a minimum of an 80 percent to successfully complete this course. Once you have finished this module you should be able to do the following: explain what horizontal gaze nystagmus is and why we test for it in standard field sobriety tests, identify the steps needed to properly administer the HDN test, recognize the key clues that indicate impairment, and finally, apply your knowledge through simulated officer scenarios, also applying it by administering the HGN test.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Let’s begin…
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Nystagmus is the involuntary jerkiness of the eyes. There are many types of nystagmus, each with its own peculiar characteristics. Normally this jerkiness is not visible to the human eye. However, when a person consumes alcohol, the eyes are unable to maintain visual fixation while moving side to side. The eyes appear to slowly drift away from the direction of the gaze and then quickly drift back. This observable phenomenon is known as Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus. It is what trained police officers look for when conducting a field sobriety test of the same name. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="As an officer, your responsibility is to administer the HGN test according to the standard procedure. Lets go ahead and go through these main steps.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Please click on each step to learn more. Once you have read more about each step you will be able to continue on with the module
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Step 1, Prepare the Subject.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="The first thing we want to do is ensure that the environment is free from distractions that could potentially affect the test results. For example...
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Visual distractions and environmental factors.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="For visual distractions, we want to ensure the subject is facing away from rotating lights, strobe lights or passing traffic.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="For environmental factors, we want to avoid windy or dusty environments that could irritate the subject’s eyes and interfere with the test.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Finally, we want to ensure the eyes are unobstructed for clear observation. We can do this by asking the subject to remove their glasses if they are wearing any.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="This preparation ensures the conditions are optimal for accurate testing and minimizes any potential interference with the subjects eye moveents.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Step 2, Position the Stimulus
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="In the second step of the HGN test, we will position the stimulus. This stimulus can be any small object, even the tip of your finger. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="We will hold the stimulus 12 to 15 inches directly in front of the subject’s nose, slightly above eye level. This distance and position will ensure that the subject can follow the stimulus without having to strain their eyes or move their head.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Maintaing this exact distance will also ensure that the 45 degree angle is properly calculated during the test and provides consistent results. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Tip: Make sure you DO NOT change the distance during the administration of the test, as this could affect the accuracy of your observations.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Step 3, Instruct the Subject
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="In the third step we will provide clear instructions to the subject regarding the HGN test. Clear communication is crucial for proper test administration. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="You will provide the following instructions to the subject:
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="- Stand still with your feet together and hands at your side.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="- Keep your head still and look at and follow this stimulus with your eyes only.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="- Keep looking at the stimulus until told the test is over.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="- Do not move your head at any time during the test.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="- Do you understand?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="These instructions are crucial because head movement can interfere with the accuracy of your observations. The subject must only move their eyes to follow the stimulus.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="It is also important for you to ensure that the subject understands these instructions before proceeding. Make sure to also remind them if they inadvertently move their head during the test.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Step 4, Check for Equal Pupil Size and Resting Nystagmus
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="This fourth step is crucial as it can tell the officer if the subject has an underlying medical condition. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="To begin this step, we will check for equal pupil size. Here we will check both pupils to ensure they are the same size. Unequal pupil size indicates a medical condition rather than an impairment. This is important as it helps us make sure there are no underlying medical conditions affecting the test results.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="We will then check for Resting Nystagmus. Here, we will observe the subject’s eyes before moving the stimulus, while the eyes are at rest. Look for any involuntary jerking when the subject is not following the stimulus. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Note, resting nystagmus can indicate either a high level of impairment or an exisiting neurological condition.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Step 5, Check for Equal Tracking
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="In step 5, we will move the stimulus smoothly from the center to the far left and far right of the subject’s field of vision, keeping a pace of 2 seconds in each direction to allow for proper observation. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Both eyesshould follow the stimulus smoothly and together without lagging or jerking. This is what we call, equal tracking.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="This step is important because unequal tracking, where one eye lags or moves differently from the other, could indicate impairment or a medical condition. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Step 6, Check for Smooth Pursuit
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="In the sixth step we will move the stimulus from the center to the far left, back to the center and then to the far right to test for smooth pursuit in each eye.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="When we check for smooth pursuit, we are checking to see if the subject’s eyes smoothly follow the stimulus without any noticeably jerking or lagging.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="It is a good idea to move the stimulus at a slow and steady pace during this step.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Step 7, Check for Nystagmus at Maximum Deviation
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="In the seventh step we will move the stimulus to the far left and far right, holding it there for a least 4 seconds on each side. During this process we will be observing the eyes for distinct and sustained nystagmus, jerking, while the eye is held at its maximum deviation.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Please note, the jerking you observe should be noticeable and sustained while the eye is at its furthest point.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="This test for nystagmus at maximum deviation is a strong indicator of impairment and should be conducted slowly and carefully to ensure accurate results.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Step 8, Check for Onset of Nystagmus Prior to 45 Degrees.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="In this final step , we will slowly move the stimulus from the center toward the subject’s shoulder, taking about 4 seconds to reach a 45 degree angle. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="In this step, we are watching for the onset of nystagmus, or jerking, before the eye reaches a 45 degree angle. This is an important indicator of impairment. If nystagmus is observed, we will want to verify if the jerking is continuous, not just a brief movement. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="We will repat this for BOTH eyes.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Please note, while administering this portion of the test, make sure some white of the eye is visible on the side closest to the ear when nystagmus is observed before 45 Degrees. This will ensure the eye is still within the field of observation and not at maximum deviation." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="After completing the HGN test, officers must fill out a checklist to ensure they have followed proper procedures and keep track of any clues they observed. For this activity, lets practice filling out that checklist by dragging the correct procedures to their respective steps. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="You will not be able to move on with the module until you have dragged each procedure to its correct step. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Good luck!" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text=" [Officer] For the next test, what I need you to do is put your feet together, heels and toes, arms down at your side. See the tip of the stimulus here? 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="[Subject] Yes. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="{Officer] What I need you to do is follow that with your eyes from side to side. Do not move your head. Do you understand that? 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="[Subject] Yes. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="[Officer]Check the eyes for equal tracking. Check the eyes for equal pupil size.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="00:43
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="[Officer] At this time, you may observe resting nystagmus. Check each eye for lack of smooth pursuit. This is an example of lack of smooth pursuit.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="01:23
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="[Officer] This is an example of nystagmus at maximum deviation. Then, check each eye for onset of nystagmus prior to 45 degrees.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="01:51
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="[Officer] This is an example of nystagmus prior to 45 degrees. Finally, check for vertical nystagmus. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="[Officer]Okay, you can relax." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Great Job so far! We are halfway through the module! We’ve learned everything we need to, in order to administer our first HGN Test! 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="In the upcoming scenario, you will be taking on the role of an officer who has just pulled over a subject suspected of impairment. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="You will need to:
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="- Determine the proper steps in administering the HGN Test
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="- Observe the subjects eyes and identify any clues of impairment
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="- and make a decision on how to proceed .
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Let’s Get Started!" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="After completing the HGN test, officers must fill out a checklist to ensure they have followed proper procedures and keep track of any clues they observed. For this activity, lets practice filling out that checklist by dragging the correct procedures to their respective steps. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="You will not be able to move on with the module until you have dragged each procedure to its correct step. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Good luck!" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text=" [Officer] For the next test, what I need you to do is put your feet together, heels and toes, arms down at your side. See the tip of the stimulus here? 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="[Subject] Yes. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="{Officer] What I need you to do is follow that with your eyes from side to side. Do not move your head. Do you understand that? 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="[Subject] Yes. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="[Officer]Check the eyes for equal tracking. Check the eyes for equal pupil size.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="00:43
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="[Officer] At this time, you may observe resting nystagmus. Check each eye for lack of smooth pursuit. This is an example of lack of smooth pursuit.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="01:23
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="[Officer] This is an example of nystagmus at maximum deviation. Then, check each eye for onset of nystagmus prior to 45 degrees.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="01:51
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="[Officer] This is an example of nystagmus prior to 45 degrees. Finally, check for vertical nystagmus. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="[Officer]Okay, you can relax." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="You stopped someone suspected of impairment. In what order should you do the following steps? Please drag each procedure to its appropriate step." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="[Officer] Please put your feet together and your arms down to your side. Look at the stimulus. Alright, follow the movement of the stimulus with your eyes only. Keep looking at the stimulus until you’re told the test is over. You understand?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="[Subject] Yes.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="What does the HGN test assess? Choose the best answer choice from the ones provided." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="What is an acceptable distance (in inches) to hold the stimulus from the subject’s nose? Please key in your response in the space provided, your answer should only contain digits." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="SUCCESS:
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Great job! You have successfully completed the HGN Test Training Module! You can review the results of your final assessment by pressing on “Review Quiz” or you can continue to the end of the module to obtain your certificate of completion by pressing on “View Certificate”
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="FAIL:
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Oh no! Sorry, you did not pass the final assessment. Please feel free to review what you got incorrect by pressing on “Review Quiz”. When you are ready, you can press on “Retry Quiz” to reattempt the final assessment." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="You have reached the end of the module, congratulations again! Please type your name and today’s date in the field provided so that you can print out your certificate of completion. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Click on continue when you are ready to go to the ending credits of this module so that you can exit." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>
